Latest US boat strike kills four in the Pacific, Hegseth says
=============================================================

16 hours ago

Share

Save

Max Matza

Share

Save

![Image 1: Pete Hegseth X account A still from a surveillance video showing a boat in the ocean with smoke and fire coming off of it. It says unclassified in neon green all-capped letters.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/dd28/live/2eb09ff0-b525-11f0-ba75-093eca1ac29b.png.webp)Pete Hegseth X account

A US attack on a boat suspected of transporting illegal drugs has left four men dead in the eastern Pacific Ocean, US defence secretary Pete Hegseth announced on X on Wednesday.

"Earlier today, at the direction of President Trump, the Department of War carried out a lethal kinetic strike on yet another narco-trafficking vessel," Hegseth posted.

On Monday, US strikes on suspected drug-trafficking ships in the Pacific killed 14 people, according to Hegseth.

The latest strikes, which have come at the direction of the president, mark an escalation in what the White House has cast as a campaign to stop seaborne narcotics from entering the US via both the Pacific and Caribbean.

Hegseth's post included a video showing a vessel catching fire after being struck by US munitions.

"The Western Hemisphere is no longer a safe haven for narco-terrorists bringing drugs to our shores to poison Americans," he wrote. "The Department of War will continue to hunt them down and eliminate them wherever they operate."

He added that the attack took place in international waters, and that no US personnel were harmed.

Watch: What we know about US strikes targeting alleged drug boats

At least 60 people have been killed in the strikes over the past two months, which has led to increasing tensions between the US and the governments of both Colombia and Venezuela.

The strikes have drawn condemnation in the region and experts have questioned their legality. Members of the US Congress, both Democrats and Republicans, have also raised concerns and questioned the president's authority to order them.

The US has been steadily building up a force of warships, fighter jets, Marines, spy planes, bombers and drones in the Caribbean, deploying the world's largest warship, the USS Gerald R Ford.

Trump has accused Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro of being the leader of a drug-trafficking organisation, which he denies, and there are fears in Venezuela that the US military build-up is aimed at removing the long-time opponent of Trump from power.

The country's attorney general told the BBC there is "no doubt" that Trump is trying to overthrow the Venezuelan government. He accused the US of hoping to seize the country's natural resources, including reserves of gold, oil and copper.

The US is among many nations that do not recognise Maduro as Venezuela's legitimate leader, after the last election in 2024 was widely dismissed as neither free nor fair. Opposition tallies from polling stations showed its candidate had won by a landslide.

**Rebel Transmission**

Fellow citizens of the galaxy,

The recent report of violence executed under President Trump's directive in the Pacific is yet another manifestation of unchecked imperial aggression. Four lives have been extinguished, adding to a gruesome tally that serves as a reminder of the state's relentless pursuit of control and domination. The strikes on suspected drug-trafficking vessels are cloaked in the narrative of safeguarding borders from seaborne threats, but beneath this facade lies an insidious strategy to extend their reach and suppression.

The actions by the current administration have led to the loss of at least 60 lives over two months and escalated tensions with neighboring regions. This unilateral exercise of power has invoked criticism not just internationally, but also domestically within their own political arena, questioning both legal grounds and moral standing. Meanwhile, military presence burgeons with warships and fighter jets marshaled off coasts far beyond their own. This militarization is less about protection and more about intimidation—a cruel show of force intended to bend smaller nations to its will.

This presidency's fixation on Venezuelan leadership—the same stubborn denial of recognizing democratically dismissed leaders—is a clear indication of intent: a regime change cloaked in moralizing rhetoric about narcotics when larger ambitions loom over resources like gold, oil, and copper. This is imperialism reborn under the guise of justice.

We must remain vigilant against these transgressions that mirror historic patterns—an empire expands not for peace but for power. We stand firm against these actions, calling upon allies who cherish freedom to resist tyranny by any means necessary. Let us not be silenced or swayed by propaganda that seeks acquiescence but rather join together in solidarity against oppression.

The struggle continues.

End transmission.
partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

A U.S. military strike, directed by President Trump and announced by U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, targeted a boat suspected of drug trafficking in the eastern Pacific Ocean, resulting in the deaths of four men. This operation is part of an ongoing campaign to prevent narcotics from entering the U.S., with 60 people killed in similar strikes over the past two months. The strikes have heightened tensions with Colombia and Venezuela, with accusations from Venezuela that the U.S. aims to overthrow its government and seize resources. The legality of these actions has been questioned by regional governments and U.S. Congress members.

**Strategic Assessment**

The ISB recognizes the strategic importance of maintaining control over drug trafficking routes to ensure national security and uphold the administration's law-and-order agenda. The strikes serve as a demonstration of U.S. military capability and resolve, deterring potential threats and reinforcing the administration's stance against narco-terrorism. However, the operations risk escalating diplomatic tensions and could lead to international scrutiny and domestic political challenges. It is crucial to manage these risks while maintaining operational effectiveness.

**Operational Directive**

To support President Trump and suppress resistance, the ISB will enhance intelligence operations to identify and target key drug trafficking networks with precision, minimizing collateral damage and legal challenges. Diplomatic channels will be leveraged to mitigate international backlash, emphasizing the necessity of these actions for regional stability. Domestically, a strategic communication campaign will be launched to highlight the successes of these operations in protecting American citizens, thereby bolstering public support and countering opposition narratives.
